It's -- quite literally -- how all of science works. You create mathematical models (equations) to match the data, and that's how you determine what the universe is doing. Here's an article I wrote about it.

People get deeply invested in all kinds of things, and I am not one to judge what those things are, but I think it is important to be aware of what exactly it is one is investing in, so one is not accidentally investing in something only because they have been told it is magic.

Oftentimes, apparent retrograde motion is explained through the example of passing a car on the highway — it looks like it’s going backward from your perspective. 

The only way it has an effect on your life is if you’re deeply invested in the apparent nightly position of a certain dot in the sky. 🧪

A science 🧪 skeet:

When a planet is “in retrograde” that means that if you were charting its position in the sky every night, for some time, it would appear to move east rather than west. The planet’s motion isn’t actually changing — it’s just an illusion of perspective because Earth is moving too.
